awd_titl_txt: Origin and Evolution of Silicate Reservoirs in the Early Earth
awd_abstract_narration:
The first two billion years of terrestrial history arguably constitute the most important period of Earth's existence. Processes acting during this period effectively determined how this initially hot and inhospitable place in the universe became our present life-accommodating world. Terrestrial history is conventionally deciphered from the geological record. Due to the dynamic nature of Earth, its surface has been periodically rejuvenated from the time the planet was born. As a result, the isotopic and chemical heterogeneities observed in modern mantle-derived rocks primarily reflect processes associated with production and recycling of continental and oceanic crust through geological time; these likely bear no relation to primordial mantle differentiation processes. It is the early geological record, particularly between 4.5 and 2.5 Ga, from which information pertaining to the origin and early evolution of the Earth is most likely to be gleaned. Isotopic signatures created in early silicate reservoirs via radioactive decay of short- and long-lived nuclides have been sampled by early terrestrial magmas, such as komatiites, and preserved in early crustal rocks. These isotopic signatures can be used to constrain the timing of formation and the nature of these, now likely vanished, reservoirs. They can also be used to decipher the history of early planetary differentiation to the point in Earth history when crust formation and recycling processes, similar to those occurring today, took over as the main driver of chemical differentiation of the Earth?s interior. 

This research project is aimed at constraining the origin and evolution of major silicate reservoirs in the early Earth. The primary goals of the proposed research are: (1) to assess whether magma ocean processes that likely occurred within the first 100 Ma of Earth history are recorded in the potentially deep mantle sources of komatiite systems, (2) to further test the hypothesis of Maier et al. (2009) that there was a detectable transition in highly siderophile element (HSE: Re, Os, Ir, Ru, Pt, Pd) abundances in komatiites from the early to late Archean, and (3) to synthesize the isotopic and HSE abundance data for the komatiite systems examined here and other well-studied komatiite systems, integrating these data into viable models for the origin and temporal evolution of the early terrestrial silicate reservoirs contributing to these komatiite systems, and evaluate mixing times of the Earth?s mantle and the timing of late accretion. In order to achieve these goals, the 146,147Sm-142,143Nd, Lu-Hf, Pt-Re-Os, and 182Hf-182W isotope systematics and the lithophile trace and HSE abundances in five komatiite systems from around the globe, spanning a time interval of ca. 3.5 Ga in Earth history, will be characterized using state-of-the-art analytical techniques and interpreted. This study will help clarify the earliest history of Earth, and, therefore, will have relevance to the long-debated question of how planets form and evolve, and may ultimately improve our understanding of the modern Earth. Some of the expected scientific advances will be the result of involvement of up to three undergraduate students as part of their required senior research thesis work, thus, providing valuable training for the future careers of these budding scientists. Support for this research will help sustain the Isotope Geochemistry Laboratory?s mission to share and collaborate world-wide. The results of the proposed work will be published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, presented at professional conferences and invited lectures, and discussed at Departmental seminars. The outreach efforts will also include collaborations between scientists from three continents.

por.por_cntn:
The first two billion years of Earth's history constitute the most important period of its existence. Processes acting during this period effectively determined how this initially hot and inhospitable place in the universe became our present life-accommodating world.

Due to the dynamic nature of Earth, manifested by continuous exchanges between the mantle and crust, and its violent and extended accretionary history, it is the early geological record, particularly between 4.5 and 2.5 Ga, from which information pertaining to the origin and early evolution of planet Earth is most likely to be gleaned. Isotopic signatures created in early silicate reservoirs have been sampled by early high-MgO magmas, called komatiites, and preserved in these rocks. These isotopic signatures can be used to constrain the timing of formation and the nature of these, now vanished, reservoirs. They can also be used to decipher the history of early planetary differentiation to the point in Earth's history when crust formation and recycling processes, similar to those occurring today, took over as the main driver of chemical differentiation of the Earth's interior.

This research Project was aimed at constraining the origin and evolution of silicate reservoirs in the early Earth. The 182W, 142,143Nd, 176Hf, and 186,187Os isotope and HSE abundance data collected provided unequivocal evidence for the presence of remarkably ancient isotope heterogeneities in the mantle that suggest that the products of the earliest planetary differentiation survived subsequent planetary accretion, accompanied by presumably vigorous mantle mixing during the Hadean, thus testifying to the very sluggish mixing times of the terrestrial mantle.

Our new results, considered together with our previously obtained data for other early and late Archean komatiite systems, showed no trend of increasing HSE abundances in the mantle from 3.5 to present. Combined, these new data indicate that, rather than slow downward mixing of an HSE-rich "late veneer" throughout the Archean, the HSE concentration variations observed in the mantle reflect sluggish mixing of (1) diverse post-magma ocean silicate domains characterized by variably-fractionated lithophile and siderophile element abundances and (2) silicate reservoirs representing mantles of large accreted differentiated impactors, bulk of which was delivered to Earth prior to 4.40 Ga. Our new data constrain the timing of the major phase of late accretion to Earth to the first 160 Ma of the Solar System history.

The grant enabled the PI to serve as a mentor to a number of graduate and undergraduate students and a visiting scientist. These included Ph.D. student Robert William Nicklas, M.Sc. student Mitchell Haller, and B.Sc. students Kyle Ludwig and Joseph Browning (UMD), as well as postdoctoral researcher Dr. Donald Ngonge (University of Sao Paolo). This training provided them with the skills essential for their future careers as geoscientists, from field recognition, mapping, and sampling komatiite lava flows and initial sample description, to sample cutting, crushing and grinding, digestion, and ion exchange chromatography, and mass-spectrometric analysis, to data reduction, modeling, and writing up scientific manuscripts, and presentation of results.

The main findings have been reported at the 2015 Spring AGU Meeting in Montreal, Canada, and at the 2015, and 2018 Goldschmidt Conferences in Prague, Czech Republic, and Boston, MA, where invited talks and a keynote lecture were given. Talks were also given at the 2016 and 2018 Fall AGU Meetings in San Francisco, CA, and Washington, DC. The PI organized and chaired a session at the 2017 Goldschmidt Conference in Paris, France, titled "Komatiites - Witnesses to Earth's History", where results have been reported in two keynote lectures and two regular presentations. The PI also presented the results at the 2017 Meeting "Global Research in the 21st Century" organized by the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation and held in Washington, D.C. This meeting provided the PI with the ample opportunity for public outreach to a broader scientific community. In 2018, the PI was invited to present results of his research at the Institute for Planetology, University of Münster, Germany.

              Three research papers have been published and two more are in preparation for publication. A review paper "Origin and Evolution of Silicate Reservoirs in the Early Earth", that the PI has been invited to write for Chemical Geology, is also in preparation. A chapter for the Encyclopedia of Geochemistry entitled "The Platinum Group Elements' that the PI was invited to contribute, has also been published. In addition, the PI published an invited paper titled "When was the Earth's conveyor belt set in motion?" highlighting the publication on Nd-Hf isotope systematics of Barberton komatiites.

           As a result of his NSF-funded research and teaching/training activity, in 2016, the PI received the prestigious Distinguished Research Scientist Award from the University of Maryland, "in recognition of his excellence in research that has raised the profile and prestige of the University", and delivered an award lecture "Young Earth and the Komatiite Zoo".
